comments.body: I'm not sure if this had some special meaning, I simplified it a bit and it seems to be fine
I think removing sources for the doc task makes it faster, that's why it was there
Although it's already set in ThisBuild so it's probably redundant here
I'd prefer to skip scaladoc and -sources.jar generation for publishLocal. Can we keep these only if `sys.env.contains("CI") == false`?
If you're only planning to use publish on CI, this is the most sensible way of doing it. 👍

But then it should be in `ThisBuild` not here, right? It's `noPublish` settings, that were used only in the test-worspace
Yes, in this build works.

comments.body:
@jvican I think this setting doesn't work as intended:

```
[warn] You must run bintrayRelease once all artifacts are staged.
[info] sbt-release-early: Releasing languageserver to Bintray.
[info] scalameta/languageserver@18606230 was released
```

It warns during publishing, so `bintrayReleaseOnPublish` is set to `false`, but then something still triggers `bintrayRelease`.
The warning comes from sbt-bintray, nothing I can do about it 👍

The warning is good! 😄 With that setting I wanted to turn off `bintrayRelease` for snapshot versions which in sbt-dynver terminology are any versions except tags (~~so I just realised that I actually wanted to use `isVersionStable` here~~ it's a task "/). 

And the warning says that `bintrayRelease` is not triggered automatically on publish (which is redefined so in sbt-bintray), but then `bintrayRelease` is still done and I suspect that sbt-release-early doesn't respect this setting.

comments.body: Can we set `name := "metalsRoot"` in the top-level? By default sbt names the root project after the directory name, unless there is a project with a conflicting in which case it creates a bogus name like "default-fd2bf4". This name appears in IntelliJ after importing the build so I think "metalsRoot" would be nice
👍 done. Thanks for explaining where the bogus name came from, also the sbt launcher displays it and I was confused.

comments.body:
can you preserve `name := "metalsRoot"` here?

The reason why it was there is that sbt uses a bogus name for the root project, because the default name (the directory) is already taken by a project.

I don't know why exactly, but when I started working on this PR, `name := "metalsRoot"` didn't work and that bodus name appeared, so I added this explicit root project declaration. Now it's called `root`, which I think is quite standard naming in multi-build projects. But if you prefer `metalsRoot`, I can rename it, no problem.

`metalsRoot` is better since this name appears in IntelliJ "Open recent"

![screen shot 2018-04-03 at 15 43 13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1408093/38252970-c72da9fe-3755-11e8-9930-586f3c1191da.png)

ah, I see.
No problem, as long as the horrible generated name doesn't show up, I'm fine with "root"!
Nevermind, what @olafurpg said :D
OK 👌
Does this destroy automatic aggregation? I think `~metals/test` stops working if you explicitly define a root project. At least `publishLocal` no longer aggregates for all defined modules.

comments.body:
I find this whole `diff` pretty hard to read. I took me a while to understand.

Doesn't this work?

```scala
scalacOptions --= Seq("-Yrangepos", "-Ywarn-unused-import")
```
I admit that this `diff` doesn't look nice. I wanted to remove `-Ywarn-unused-import` only on Scala 2.10, but I guess it's not important, I'll change it to `--=` 👍
you can apply the filter on that `Seq` too, but unless it's necessary I would avoid complicating it.

comments.body: are you replicating the `^` logic by hand? Was it broken?
I get it now, thanks :)

The primary motivation was to use `+` instead of `^`, it's conceptually easier IMO to have to only think about the Scala version, especially when it comes to publishing all modules. I think sbt doesn't work this way by default in order to be able to hypothetically support multiple sbt versions on the same Scala version.
is this still in use?
Nope, ls4ps is not strictly used either because the `metals` project has 2 source files at the moment. I will clean up the `metals` project once we add language server stuff.
I meant the interactive part specifically, but there's no rush to clean this up now, I agree

comments.body: @milessabin One option for syncing the CI with `crossScalaVersions` is to automatically generate `.travis.yml` from build.sbt. In this PR we're using GitHub Actions but the same approach should work for Travis CI.

@olafurpg you must be pulling my leg ... @djspiewak told me this is "fundamentally impossible"! ;-)

But seriously ... thanks for the pointer :-)
It doesn't even seem necessary to print YAML, you can print JSON as long as the filename stays `travis.yml`

> In this PR we're using GitHub Actions but the same approach should work for Travis CI.

It doesn't work with travisci unless you commit the results. If Github Actions has multi-stage builds without a need to hard-commit results and allowing configuration shifts between stages, then it would be capable of this, but Travis' architecture doesn't support that.

> It doesn't work with travisci unless you commit the results.

When did I ever say I didn't want to commit the results!?!

comments.body: This change is not needed
I add it per project, because it fails when added to a dotty project.
Added separateSettings to all 2.12 project.

It would be nice if we can fold this into the `mtags` module with `crossScalaVersions = List(2.12, 2.13, 0.23)`. That would allow us to share more code between scala 2 and 3. We may have to move Scala 2 specific code into a `scala-2` source directory but that's fine.

You can see how we configuire this setup in MUnit here https://github.com/scalameta/munit/blob/f22d9c3d841668f3aebaeaf0819438ca53fab7c5/build.sbt#L125-L146

@olafurpg Any idea how to disable the scalafix plugin based on Scala version? That's why I initially moved it into two modules. They do reuse a common directory for any common code, which I think is a bit simpler to do.

Is there actual need to have it in a single module?

Also we don't have fiddle with the settings and numerous edge cases if we keep them in separate modules. 

I sharing code currently via:
```
 Compile / unmanagedSourceDirectories += file("mtags-common") / "src/main/scala",
```

Do you need to disable the Scalafix plugin? As long as you don't run `scalafix` after `++0.21.0...` it's fine. We currently only run Scalafix on 2.12 (not 2.11 or 2.13). We can update sbt-scalafix to special handle Dotty so that the plugin doesn't do anything by default, it's a small fix.

It's desirable to have a single mtags module:

* no custom logic to resolve mtags3 instead of mtags
* idiomatic code reuse via `mtags/src/main/{scala,scala-2,scala-3,...}` folder structure. I have almost always regretted customizing my sbt build outside of these conventions.

Dotty is in my view just another Scala version and it we should try to use `crossScalaVersions` where possible to support it.

My biggest motivation to have a single mtags module is that we already use `crossScalaVersions` to abstract over 2.11/2.12/2.13. It would be a step backwards to add a different abstraction to support 0.x or 3.x

> no custom logic to resolve mtags3 instead of mtags

We will still need custom logic to resolve it, but I can see how hard it would to merge them.
Merged the directories together, but kept the modules separate, otherwise it will not be possible to have language support in Scala 3 build target, since targets correspond to modules.
it could be `def isScala212(v: Option[(Long, Long)]): Boolean = v.contains((2,12))`

comments.body: I know we briefly hit on this before, but why do we say that `2.13.0` is deprecated, but not `2.12.10`. I fee like we should be consistent with that across 2.12 and 2.13.

`2.13.0` was released a while ago and had a couple of issue, so I don't think we can recommend that. `2.13.1` was quickly released with the fixes. `2.12.10` is still in use by a lot of codebases and it`s only recently that the new version was released.
Alright, that makes sense.

comments.body: So I see this is added in order to access `BuildInfo` in `ScalaPresentationCompiler.scala`, but why isn't it detected by default here?
It's the `mtags3` module, which I added so that we have the additional target. It uses `mtags3` directory by default, so every source dir from mtags needs to be added manually.

comments.body: This ensures that if the test is not found then it will go into the first group

Just a note, but I've noticed the build definition is getting pretty large. I'm normally in favor of starting to move methods out into `project/x` once things start getting this large. Just something to think about for the future as we continually add more.

It seems that we have a large regression in 0.27 and no completions coming from scala library are not displayed.
This way most large tests will be run on 0.26, which works and I will focus on fixing it upstream before the release.
Link to the regression https://github.com/lampepfl/dotty/issues/9760
